awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Assistive Control System Harnessing Vestigial Neuromuscular Biosignals
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will continue the work started in the Phase I project to fully explore the extent to which signals from the vestigial muscles around the ears can be repurposed as a new human ability. Higher primates have not needed these muscles for millions of years, yet they exist in nearly everyone and are controlled by nerves that come directly from the brainstem, thereby bypassing the spinal to cord to remain functional after even the highest spinal cord injuries. This project involves the development of an optimized headset controller device, along with the testing and evaluation of this new control modality in a variety of real-world applications that would be useful for both paralyzed and able-bodied people.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be significant in the assistive technology space. Limitations of mobility and interpersonal interaction are primary factors determining functional independence and quality of life in people with physical disabilities, yet existing assistive devices remain cumbersome and usurp the individual's few remaining still-functioning motor systems. This innovation in assistive technology could bring a new controller to those with paralysis or limb loss, and has the potential to change how anyone interfaces with their environment. Users would, in essence, develop a new mode of command output that can be operated intuitively, invisibly, and wirelessly.

por.por_cntn:
Reach Bionics, with the support of this National Science Foundation SBIR grant, has developed new hands-free assistive device controllers for people with spinal cord injuries and other forms of paralysis. 

Our Peri-Auricular Muscle (PAM) controller is a wearable headset that captures electromyography (EMG) signals from the ear muscles and processes them into commands that it can send wirelessly to target devices. Because the controller does not occupy any established muscles that the paralyzed user would otherwise use, but rather opens up an unused output, it is particularly well suited for individuals with assistive device needs who do not wish to sacrifice any of their other remaining abilities. PAM was tested over the course of a clinical study at USC, in which we collaborated with the Department of Physical Therapy to develop a training regimen for teaching users to control their ear muscles. Considerable technical progress was made in the design and build of this headset over the course of the Phase 2 grant period, and the system was successfully used to play video games, control a computer interface, and drive a wheelchair. 

We also began the development of an implantable PAM with the help of our research partners at the University of Washington. A clinical study in collaboration with their Center for Sensorimotor Neural Engineering (CSNE) supported the modification of their microelectronic implant technology for our peri-auricular EMG purposes, and supported a clinical study to do proof-of-concept testing. Improvements made here will likely improve PAM’s usability for people with paralysis, since training can be reduced and the need to take on or off the headset is eliminated. 

In an effort to broaden our market for this technology, we also modified our system to create a new EMG controller called Conjure. Conjure uses the same platform as PAM, but was redesigned to capture EMG signals during facial gestures as a source of command signals. Conjure is worn like a pair of ski goggles in which the foam liner incorporates embedded sensors capable of recording EMG generated as the user makes basic facial gestures. The design eliminates the need for training and significantly reduces the complexity of the headset. Conjure has applications as an assistive device (Conjure Assist) and has potential consumer applications for able-bodied individuals such as a hands-free control of virtual reality headsets (Conjure VR).

All of the major goals of this SBIR project were achieved. We built the PAM controller, identified a training approach for the periauricular musculature, implemented a real-time adaptive learning algorithm for user and software co-training, and designed a biofeedback gaming environment to train and test subjects. This project has ultimately resulted in new improved ways for people to interact with their world, and has borne several new technologies that are currently being commercialized.
